title: Walking Couch
text:
Welcome to our final project for Mechanical Design, a course at Harvey Mudd College focused on mechanical principles, analysis techniques, group design workflows, and product development.


Introduction
This project focuses on the physical design, analysis, and implementation of an electromechanical Jansen linkage system capable of carrying a couch and passenger, allowing for stylish transport around Harvey Mudd‚Äôs campus. Further information about technical specifics and design decisions can be found in the tabs at the top of the page.




Requirements

Walk using the Jansen linkage

Carry 1 passenger
Recline

Electromechanically powered

Steerable




Specifications

Hold 500 lbs

Transfer torque via chain-sprocket linkage

Lifecycle of >30 minutes

Move >2 mph






Stretch Goals


Move 5 mph


Hold 2 people


Able to navigate hallways of Harvey Mudd


<70 dB





Future Work


Upgrade to 12 legs for smoother movement enabled by a 120¬∞ phase offset (currently 180¬∞)


Decrease gear ratio to achieve higher speeds


Replace bushings in leg joints with ball bearings to extend operating lifetime


Add an enclosure for electronics and chain linkage





Conclusion

title: Design and Simulation
text:
Crankshaft
This design allows us to transfer torque from the reduction stage into the legs. Our initial plan was to use 12 total legs‚Äîthree at each corner‚Äîwhich required either a long crankshaft, simulated below, or numerous sprockets and chains. The simulation highlighted key issues in our design.



SolidWorks FEA Simulation for Crankshaft


The long crankshaft introduced undesirable failure modes and increased design complexity, while the sprockets and chains exceeded our budget. Based on the simulation, we made two key decisions that ultimately contributed to the success of our project.

Decision 1:
We moved from 12 legs to 8 legs, with only 2 per corner, reducing the length of the crankshaft and decreasing the localized torque experienced near the crankshaft‚Äôs sprocket.


Decision 2:
We increased the thickness of the steel bars used for the crankshaft to reduce the risk of torsional failure modes that may have been overlooked in the idealized simulation.

title: Ideation
text:
With inspiration originally derived from the Strandbeest Bike video titled Epic Cycling | Truly Unique Bicycle that Walks on YouTube, created by Brandon Green at the Dallas Makerspace, this project aims to extend the concept to an electromechanical system capable of supporting the weight of a couch and a passenger.



Dallas Makerspace ‚ÄúRogue Strandbeest Mk2 Build [COMPLETE]‚Äù - Brandon_Green


This idea was further explored by Nebiyu Samuel and Scarlett Bonner in E175: Dynamics of Rigid Bodies at Harvey Mudd College, taught by Professor Lori Bassman. In their report titled ‚ÄúModeling a Strandbeest Bike‚Äù found at the bottom of this page, Nebiyu and Scarlett drew from knowledge learned in E175 to analyze footpath, kinetic energy, and power requirements needed to run this complex mechanical system.
It is important to note that while our design was inspired by previous work with the Jansen linkage like seen in the bike image, we instead take advantage of specific weight-bearing properties from the Carpentopod design shown and linked below.

title: Manufacturing
text:
Legs
The legs were manufactured from 3/4-inch wooden cutouts using the ShopBot machine in the Harvey Mudd machine shop. Each leg accounted for both slipping and non-slipping joints, with either bushing carriages (shown below) or secure bolts mounted accordingly. In total, we fabricated eight legs.



Bushing assembly used for rotational joints on the legs


In addition to the bolt and bushing connections, one more connection was required to complete the leg assemblies. As seen below, 3D-printed spacers, a generous amount of 5-minute epoxy, and six wood screws were used to clamp these sections‚Äîoptimized to withstand the expected shear forces.



Glued and screwed section of our leg assembly


Due to the compactness of our design and the hardware available at Harvey Mudd College, the previously 4-inch-long, 1/2-inch-diameter bolts were cut nearly flush with each joint to prevent interference within the assembly, as seen on the right in the image of the finished legs below.







‚ÄúBrackets‚Äù
The components we refer to as brackets serve as mounting points for the axle and fixed sections of the crankshaft connected to the frame. The assembly features a dual bearing design using 1/2-inch steel rods, 1-inch steel tubing, and 3/4-inch square beams. A complete bracket assembly is shown below, including bearing placement and a 3D-printed spacer that keeps the bearings near the tubing edge to maximize resistance to bending moments. Specific dimensions are available in the CAD ZIP file linked on the homepage.




Ensuring proper alignment during bracket assembly is crucial, as they support long 1/2-inch steel beams that serve as crankshaft mounts and axle blocks. Extreme care was taken using bearings, 1/2-inch steel rods, long bolts, clamps, and scrap 80/20 bars as guides to achieve precise alignment across all brackets as shown below.



DIY aligment fixture





Frame
The frame refers to the top portion of the full assembly, where the couch mounts above and the motor and reduction assemblies mount below. Four 3-foot-long angle irons were welded into a square, with 80/20 bars screwed in parallel along two sides. An additional four 80/20 bars were attached to the top, serving as mounting points for the couch, motor, and reduction stages. This configuration provides flexibility in positioning the motor and reduction assemblies, allowing for proper spring tensioning during final assembly.







Reduction Stage
As determined in the Design & Simulation section, a total gear reduction of 16:1 is required. Since each motor drives two pairs of legs (front and back on one side), the reduction must be achieved in two stages. The reduction stage shown below represents the first step. A key feature of this component is that it converts a single input (the large gear) into two outputs (the smaller gears), with one driving the front legs and the other driving the back legs on the same side of the walking couch.




The pillow blocks in this design are made from 100% infill PLA 3D-printed material and include press-fit bearings. The shaft features three sprockets and a range of differently sized spacers, visible between the sprockets in the image above and below. These spacers provide flexibility during the assembly process.




Couch
We used Dominick‚Äôs college futon, which was originally slightly too long. To adapt it, we shortened it to approximately 3 feet wide while preserving its ability to recline‚Äîa critical feature. After all, when riding a walking couch across a college campus, one must be sufficiently reclined to truly convey just how cool they really are.
